issues.title: Spelling mistake
issues.body:
#0006 queued by 'tris' ]

   Filename: '1 - 01 - Torch Song.mp3'
   Artist:   'AFI'
   Title:    'Torch Song'
   Album:    'Crash Love'
   Genre:    'Rock'
   Year:     2009
   Audio:     225s   44100hz   247kbps   2 channels
   Votes needed to skip:    3
   Could not auhtenticate. Log in to enable vote-off functionality.

WTF is auhtenticate?!?

issue_comments.body:
The server would not need to initiate communications - the client would do a np request and the server would reply with the additional details.

Getting the details however is the tricky part, and if it is not easy then the android client will just have to poll every medium interval - small enough to refresh frequently, large enough to prolong battery life.

If the user wants up-to-date details then they can simply click on the playlist and a new np request will be made. I think this is the optimal solution as of present.

issues.title: Improve Scripting Support
issues.body:
Simple scripting support has been added. We should add new hooks.
- Nothing to play
- VO
- song added

issues.title: stop the silence!
issues.body: When nothing is in the queue support playing from a pls or an internet stream.

issues.title: SSL certs
issues.body: We are using SSL, but we don't check the certs.  So people could impersonate the server.

issues.title: Streaming Support
issues.body: We currently use headphone splitter / speakers, can we add support for mp3 streaming?

issues.title: Fair-play mode.
issues.body:
At the moment one user can queue up a bunch of songs, and every one else has to wait for all that person's songs to finish before their song plays.

Add a fair play mode when songs are placed at the next "fair" position.  How this is implemented needs some though.

On 8 Jul 2011 17:18, "gairne" <
reply@reply.github.com>
wrote:

> The android app will need to keep updating the playlist when a song ends /
> gets voted off and a new one is playing. One naive approach is to poll every
> second to check for a new song.
> 
> This is problematic on a mobile platform as some users may not appreciate
> data being constantly sent, draining battery life.
> 
> A slightly better way is to intelligently guess when you may need to
> change the song by utilising the track length and the amount of the track
> already played at time of playlist request.
> 
> Is it easy to extend the protocol to accommodate current time and total
> track time? If not, then we might just provide users with a refresh button
> if they are desperate for a playlist update, and then just poll every 10
> seconds or so.
> 
> ## 
> 
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub:
> https://github.com/vext01/hgd/issues/66

issues.title: Why no safe variant of skip?
issues.body:
vo has a safe variant,
why not skip?

issues.title: How to know if a track is paused?
issues.body: Tracks seem to keep their paused state, so could there be a way to know this in clients over the network protocol?

issues.title: Allow uses to dequeue tracks.
issues.body: One of the lphack features we don't have in hgd yet is dequeuing tracks.

issues.title: Sending HUP to server doesn't kick clients.
issues.body:
if you use kill -HUP and the pid of the main server.
Have to use pkill to get it to work.

issues.title: Get length of track played.
issues.body:
To create a scrobbler, a client must know how much of a song has played.
Is this possible?
Thanks,
Tris

issues.title: Anti flooding with the same track.
issues.body:
At the moment, a user can have a maximum number of tracks in the queue, but if Sav gets any madder, we could conceivably end up with 5 copies of the seagulls sound effects in the queue at the same time.

Could it be possible to limit the number of the same track submitted by any one user (in the queue obviously, people might want to queue something from earlier in the day later on).

Tris

issue_comments.body: This would be a great idea. I will be working on an Android client very soon.
Won't this encourage users to "spam" the system?
This would be great for clients.
No point doing it then.
I like this idea.
I just opened an issue separately but it would also be good for clients to get the admin level of the logged in user.
Could there also be a way of asking "have I voted this track off"?
Yes this seems to be done now.
Thanks. I can't do anything with it until it's available over the network.
The track would be deemed the same if it has the same filename and filesize.

or that.

I have no log at the moment but steps to reproduce are:
- Run netd and playd.
- Queue one song
- Vote it off
- Run ls. voted? will be "1"
- Let song finish, or skip it.
- Queue another song.
- Run ls. voted? will be "1".  ==[BUG]
- Run ls. voted? will be "0".

On Fri, Jul 08, 2011 at 08:18:37AM -0700, gairne wrote:

> The android app will need to keep updating the playlist when a song ends / gets voted off and a new one is playing. One naive approach is to poll every second to check for a new song.
> 
> This is problematic on a mobile platform as some users may not appreciate data being constantly sent, draining battery life.
> 
> A slightly better way is to intelligently guess when you may need to change the song by utilising the track length and the amount of the track already played at time of playlist request.
> 
> Is it easy to extend the protocol to accommodate current time and total track time? If not, then we might just provide users with a refresh button if they are desperate for a playlist update, and then just poll every 10 seconds or so.

No, it is not easy. We would need to run mplayer in slave mode to get the time,
but worse than that, the server can not initiate "conversations", the client
always requests something first, as you know. Currently my client is polling.

If you know a simple way to accomplish this, shout.

Let's get teh basics down first, then we can look at how the protocol can be
extended in the distant future.

## 

Best Regards
Edd Barrett

http://www.theunixzoo.co.uk

On Fri, Jul 08, 2011 at 08:44:10AM -0700, gairne wrote:

> The server would not need to initiate communications - the client would do a np request and the server would reply with the additional details.
> 
> Getting the details however is the tricky part, and if it is not easy then the android client will just have to poll every medium interval - small enough to refresh frequently, large enough to prolong battery life.
> 
> If the user wants up-to-date details then they can simply click on the playlist and a new np request will be made. I think this is the optimal solution as of present.

OK, I see ehat you mean now, I though you meant teh server was to "notify"
clients that a song has ended.

Yes, slave mode mplayer is on the TODO list.

this seems to be a linux thing.

You should not have to exceed the the vote off count. Upon receiving a vote that makes the number of votes received match the vote count, the track is skipped. If this is not the case, then there is an off by one; if so, then please file a bug (although I just tested this here and it works fine. If I recall correctly this there _used_ to be an off by one, but not now).

To be clear, if the vote count is 1 and 1 vote is received, the track is skipped.

Please back this out mex.

OK, the reason for this is as follows:
- hgd_play_track (mplayer.o) has python hooks inside.
- hgd-netd and hgd-admin use mplayer pipe sends to control mplayer (also in mplayer.o).
- Thus any binary using mplayer.o needs python linkage.

Resolution:
- move hgd_play_track() into hgd-playd.c
- remove python linkage from hgd-admin and hgd-netd

Sorry guys and gals. Nothing but warnings though I know it's important.

Currently running Fedora 13 (excuse the age I'm a slacker) I can provide more version details if necessary.

$ make 2>errors; cat errors | xsel -i

and you've got the following

py.c: In function ‘hgd_py_meth_dealloc’:
py.c:257: warning: suggest explicit braces to avoid ambiguous ‘else’
py.c:259: warning: suggest explicit braces to avoid ambiguous ‘else’
hgd-mk-pydoc.c: In function ‘hgd_mk_pydoc’:
hgd-mk-pydoc.c:91: warning: suggest explicit braces to avoid ambiguous ‘else’

hgd-mk-pydoc.c:95: warning: suggest explicit braces to avoid ambiguous ‘else’
hgd-mk-pydoc.c:56: warning: unused variable ‘args’

Using built-in specs.
Target: x86_64-redhat-linux
Configured with: ../configure --prefix=/usr --mandir=/usr/share/man --infodir=/usr/share/info --with-bugurl=http://bugzilla.redhat.com/bugzilla --enable-bootstrap --enable-shared --enable-threads=posix --enable-checking=release --with-system-zlib --enable-__cxa_atexit --disable-libunwind-exceptions --enable-gnu-unique-object --enable-languages=c,c++,objc,obj-c++,java,fortran,ada --enable-java-awt=gtk --disable-dssi --with-java-home=/usr/lib/jvm/java-1.5.0-gcj-1.5.0.0/jre --enable-libgcj-multifile --enable-java-maintainer-mode --with-ecj-jar=/usr/share/java/eclipse-ecj.jar --disable-libjava-multilib --with-ppl --with-cloog --with-tune=generic --with-arch_32=i686 --build=x86_64-redhat-linux
